required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Chronic Back Pain With Focused Vibroacoustic Stimulation
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment of Chronic Back Pain With Focused Vibroacoustic Stimulation

brief_summary.textblock:
Chronic back and neck pain is the most common chronic condition worldwide. Unfortunately, the current available treatment options are limited and largely unsuccessful, which is considered as one of the primary drivers for the high cost of back pain management. Systematic reviews show that the results of common treatments including pain medications, surgery, exercise and psychological therapies for back pain demonstrate inconsistent results and moderate improvement. Therefore, non-invasive adjunct therapies can be a useful addition to traditional back pain management.
Focused vibroacoustic treatment for back and neck pain is a non-invasive procedure that applies low frequency sound waves to the spine (50Hz-110Hz), and has shown consistent and positive results in early clinical and animal studies. The goal of this project is to test vibroacoustic sound waves delivered to the spine in a double blind randomized controlled trial to demonstrate the efficacy of focused vibroacoustics in treating chronic back pain.
Participants with back pain will be recruited and divided into a treatment and placebo group and will undergo treatment at a clinic over a one month period. Outcome measures will be collected before and after the intervention period. Placebo participants will be offered the full treatment without charge after the experiment is over.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Parallel double blind randomized controlled trial
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)
study_design_info.masking_description: There are two groups (treatment and placebo). The treatment is to stimulate vibroacoustic waves at the spine. The placebo is to stimulate vibroacoustic waves at the trapezius muscle. Participants will not know which group they are in until the end. Outcome assessors are separate from the intervention administrator and are blinded. Care providers are separate and blinded. Investigators who supervise the study are blinded. Only treatment administrators and the post doctoral research manager are informed.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of Visual Analog Scale for Pain
primary_outcome.description: A scale which measures the intensity of pain. Scored from 0 to 100. 0 means no pain, 100 means maximum pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline of Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire
Change in baseline of EuroQol (EQ5D-5L) Questionnaire
Change in Neck Pain Disability Index

secondary_outcome.description: The assessor will ask what medications the participant is taking. They will record the drug and dosage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Shoulder and Pelvis tilt
Change in Cervical range of motion
Change in Palpatory tenderness of the spine
secondary_outcome.description: The assessor will count and record the number of tender regions along the spine.

arm_group.description: Intervention is applied to the C1 of the spine.
Intervention is applied in reduced intensity to the trapezius muscle.
Participants will have a 1 month waitlist period where no intervention takes place.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of chronic low back pain with a disease duration of more than 3 months (further diagnostic results were not required)
- Aged 18-75.
- Scored at least 4/10 in pain scale (VAS or Numerical)
- Written consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Acute back pain
- Protrusion or prolapse of 1 or more intervertebral discs with concurrent neurological symptoms
- Radicular pain
- Prior vertebral column surgery
- Infectious spondylopathy
- Low back pain caused by inflammatory, malignant, or autoimmune disease
- Congenital deformation of the spine (except for slight lordosis or scoliosis)
- Compression fracture caused by osteoporosis
- Spinal stenosis
- Spondylolysis or spondylolisthesis
- Severe abdominal distension
- Smokers (more than 3 cigarettes per day or a history of severe smoking)
- Alcohol drinkers >7 glasses per week
- Previous spinal surgery
- Morbid Obesity
- Back pain from pregnancy
- Back pain from neurodegeneration
- Uncontrolled diabetics

reference.citation: Desmoulin GT, Yasin NI, Chen DW. Spinal mechanisms of pain control. Clin J Pain. 2007 Sep;23(7):576-85.

Desmoulin GT, Hewitt CR, Hunter CJ. Disc strain and resulting positive mRNA expression from application of a noninvasive treatment. Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2011 Jun 15;36(14):E921-8. doi: 10.1097/BRS.0b013e3181fd78b3.

Desmoulin GT, Reno CR, Hunter CJ. Free axial vibrations at 0 to 200 Hz positively affect extracellular matrix messenger ribonucleic acid expression in bovine nucleus pulposi. Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2010 Jul 1;35(15):1437-44. doi: 10.1097/BRS.0b013e3181c2a8ec.
